MARK CAVENDISH SHATTERS TOUR DE FRANCE RECORD: THE MANX MISSILE SOARS TO 35 STAGE WINS

Cycling fans worldwide are buzzing with excitement as Mark Cavendish, the "Manx Missile," has etched his name into the annals of Tour de France history. On a scorching day in Saint-Vulbas, France, Cavendish sprinted to a spectacular victory, securing his 35th stage win in the world's most prestigious cycling race. This win not only solidifies his status as one of the greatest sprinters of all time but also breaks the long-standing record previously held by the legendary Eddy Merckx.

A LEGACY DEFINED BY SPEED AND RESILIENCE

Cavendish's journey to this historic moment has been nothing short of extraordinary. Hailing from the Isle of Man, he burst onto the cycling scene with a raw talent for sprinting that quickly earned him the nickname "Manx Missile." With lightning-fast acceleration and a fierce determination, he dominated the sprint finishes in the Tour de France, racking up wins year after year.

However, his path to glory was not without its challenges. Cavendish faced setbacks due to illness, injury, and even a battle with depression. Yet, he displayed unwavering resilience and a burning desire to return to the top of the sport.

A RECORD-BREAKING SPRINT FOR THE AGES

The stage win that cemented Cavendish's place in history was a masterclass in sprinting. With his Astana-Qazaqstan team setting the perfect lead-out, Cavendish timed his acceleration to perfection, surging past his rivals in the final meters to cross the finish line first. The emotions that poured out as he realized the magnitude of his achievement were a testament to his passion and dedication to the sport.

A DEFINING MOMENT FOR CYCLING

Cavendish's victory is not only a personal triumph but also a moment that will be remembered by cycling enthusiasts for generations to come. Breaking Eddy Merckx's record, which stood for nearly five decades, is a monumental achievement that speaks volumes about Cavendish's skill, tenacity, and unwavering spirit.

WHAT'S NEXT FOR THE MANX MISSILE?

As Cavendish basks in the glow of his historic win, the question of what lies ahead for him remains. Will he continue racing in search of even more stage wins? Or will he decide to retire on top, leaving behind a legacy that will be difficult to match? Regardless of his decision, one thing is certain: Mark Cavendish's name will forever be etched in the hearts of cycling fans worldwide.

Mark Cavendish's 35th Tour de France stage win is a testament to the power of perseverance, dedication, and the unwavering pursuit of one's dreams. He has shown the world that even in the face of adversity, it is possible to achieve greatness. As the Manx Missile continues to inspire a new generation of cyclists, his legacy will live on, reminding us all of the extraordinary feats that can be accomplished with hard work, passion, and a never-give-up attitude.

I’m regularly on rides in the evening, starting with a clear sky, rolling through dusk, and ending at night. I could wear a set of glasses with clear lenses, or maybe even bring two glasses for different times of day. Photochromic lenses let me do both.

Photochromic lenses don’t offer quite as much vision clarity in the middle of the day as a polarized lens, nor are they quite as clear at night as a clear lens. But during the winter months where light seems to always vary? I’m grabbing my transition glasses and preparing for the scorn of 8-year-olds.

To note, my go-to has been the Limar Horus glasses with their photochromic lens. The lens is big and the optics are distortion-free. Its adaptable nose piece lets me keep the glasses close to my eyes too, and the lenses proved to be durable among myriad bikepacking trips and plenty of nighttime gravel rides.
